Award.AwardTitle: Investing in the future of paleoclimate research: U.S. graduate student fellowships for the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds graduate student participation in the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology (USSP). Held at the University of Urbino, in Italy, the USSP leverages the expertise of top quality faculty from Europe (~2/3) and the US (~1/3) to provide a three-week intensive, immersive learning experience in paleoclimate research topic and methods for both European and American students. These students present their own research and participate in lecture- and lab-style classes while broadening their research networks in an international setting. Faculty and students interact closely during the program in both formal and informal venues. Each session of the USSP brings in a new group of students and provides fresh opportunities for international collaboration. The experience of previous students suggests that participation in the USSP lays a foundation for international collaboration, both with their peers and with more senior (i.e., faculty) researchers.

Funding provides scholarships for ten US students to participate in the USSP each summer. Scholarships will be awarded on a competitive basis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving our understanding of global climate dynamics is increasingly important as humans continue to perturb the Earth system at geologically instantaneous rates. One approach is the computer-based modeling of climate dynamics and another is the reconstruction of climate history from natural archives (e.g., sediments, ice cores, fossils, etc.). The field of paleoclimatology strives to integrate these complementary approaches, and views resulting model-reconstruction differences as targets for focused investigation and improved understanding. This synergistic approach strengthens our collective scientific framework for evaluating the tempo and mode of climate changes that are increasingly driven by anthropogenic forcing.

To promote this synergistic approach in the next generation of paleoclimatologists, since 2004 a group of international teacher-scholars has collaborated to offer the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology (USSP) at the Università degli Studi di Urbino in Urbino, Italy. The USSP currently provides ~70 early-career graduate students with an intensive two-and-a-half week program in reconstructing the history and dynamics of Cretaceous to sub-modern climate through an integrated series of lectures, investigations, case-studies, and field work. Complementing these formal course components, informal scientific interactions among faculty and students are promoted through discussion and integration sessions, coffee breaks, panel discussions, poster sessions, and an embedded mini-conference. This unique convergence of disciplinary specialists and early-career graduate students provides an excellent opportunity to promote communication and collaboration on an international scale. A 11-minute video overviewing the USSP and celebrating its tenth anniversary is available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IwJMdMHQRRs. 

In earlier USSPs, the United States was well-represented at the instructor-level, but under-represented at the student-level. To increase U.S. student participation, this NSF award provided ten competitively-awarded USSP student scholarships in 2012, 2013, and 2014 that covered airfare, course costs, and a stipend for incidental expenses. This student support is consistent with the broader mission of the NSF, and complements the NSF-supported research of many U.S. instructors who volunteer significant amounts of their time and energy to prepare and deliver the USSP. Such student support can be viewed as an “early investment” in continuing to improve our understanding of the history and dynamics of the global climate system and its sensitivity to anthropogenic forcing factors.
